facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by Supreme Court on 30th June 1953 from Judgment dated 25th April 1953 of Judicial Commissioner Ajmer

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by- the Supreme Court on the 30th June, 1953, from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953, of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1953 and Criminal Reference No. 19 of 1953 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 18th March, 1953, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment and Order dated 25th April 1953 by Judicial Commissioner Ajmer in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1953 arising from Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953, of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1953 and Criminal Reference No. 19 of 1953 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 18th March, 1953, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment and Order dated 18th March 1953 by Sessions Judge Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 18th March, 1953, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: On 16th July 1952 Mangilal received letter Exhibit P-5 demanding Rs 5000

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th of July, 1952, Mangilal deceased, partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar, received by express delivery post a letter Exhibit P-5 in a closed cover Exhibit P-6.

facts.text: Letter purported sent by Bhayankar Daku Dal demanding payment of Rs 5000 at 6-30 pm on 17th July at crossing near 27th milestone Ajmer-Bijainagar road with death threat

anchor.surface_text: received by express delivery post a letter Exhibit P-5 in a closed cover Exhibit P-6. This letter was actually delivered to, Mangilals son Laduram who, on reading it, found that it purported to have been sent by Bhayankar Daku Dal demanding payment of Rs. 5,000 at 6-30 p.m. on the 17th of July at the -crossing near the 27th milestone on the Ajmer-Bijainagar road and -saying that if you cheat or do 420 or in case you inform the police, no other punishment except that of death will be meted out to you and you will be shot dead and made to lie on the ground.

facts.text: Laduram took letter to uncle Ramjas at Ajmer and they saw Superintendent of Police who took no action

anchor.surface_text: Laduram took the .original letter with the envelope to his uncle Ramjas at Ajmer and both of them saw the Superintendent of Police and gave him the letter and the envelope and asked for immediate protection and investigation. The Superintendent of Police, however, took no action in this behalf.

facts.text: On 17th July about 9-30 pm two persons one in khaki suit one in blue suit came to Mangilal shop

anchor.surface_text: Mangilal failed to comply with the demand ,to pay On the 17th of July about 9-30 p.m. when he was sitting at his shop and his munim Gajanand was writing the accounts two persons came from the neighbouring street. One of them was dressed in a khaki suit and the other in a blue suit.

facts.text: Man in blue demanded reply to letter man in khaki took Mangilals gun from shop

anchor.surface_text: The man in blue demanded from Mangilal a reply to the letter, while the man in khaki entered the shop and removed Mangilals gun which was hanging in a canvas case from a 1136 peg on the wall of the shop.

facts.text: Man in blue fired Mauser pistol killing Mangilal after he said son took letter to Ajmer

anchor.surface_text: On Mangilals replying that his son Laduram had taken the letter to Ajmer, the person dressed in blue fired from a Mauser pistol and shot Mangilal dead. The two assailants then ran away.

facts.text: Assailants threw Mauser pistol and khaki clothes near shop

anchor.surface_text: The two assailants then ran away. On the way they threw the Mauser pistol and khaki clothes in the street at a short distance from the shop. Mangilal died shortly afterwards.

facts.text: First information report lodged by Nand Lal PW1 at 9-45 pm on 17 July 1952

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was lodged by Nand Lal  P. W.1  immediately after the occurrence at 9-45 p.m. In this report Nand Lal described the occurrence in the following terms

facts.text: Prosecution charged Hem Raj Hukum Singh Milap Singh Abdul Hakim with conspiracy to send threatening letter Exhibit P-5

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution challaned four persons, viz., Hem Raj, appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1953, Hukum Singh, respondent in Criminal Appeal No. 87 of 1953, Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim. It was alleged that all the four of them had acted in conspiracy and realised, money from rich persons through threatening letters and in pursuance of the conspiracy Exhibit P-5 was sent.

facts.text: Hem Raj and Hukum Singh arrested evening of 26th July 1952 at Bijainagar sent to jail 28th July 1952

anchor.surface_text: Hem Raj and Hukum Singh were arrested on the evening of the 26th July at Bijainagar and were sent to jail on the 28th of July, 1952.

facts.text: Hem Raj made confession on 30th July 1952 before Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th of July, 1952, Hem Raj made a confession in jail before a Magistrate.

facts.text: Confession retracted by Hem Raj on 5th September 1952 before committing Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th of September, 1952, at the first hearing of the case before the committing Magistrate, the confession was retracted by means of an application made through counsel

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh acquitted Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim

anchor.surface_text: Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim were acquitted by the learned Sessions Judge who how- ever convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh of the different offences with which they had been charged.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner dismissed Hem Raj appeal allowed Hukum Singh appeal

anchor.surface_text: Hukum Singhs appeal was allowed but that of Hem Raj was dismissed. As stated already, Hem Rajs appeal before us is by special leave and the State has also appealed against the acquittal of Hukum Singh

facts.text: Hem Raj claimed confession not voluntary preceded by inducement illegal custody from 25 July

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that Hem Raj was actually arrested on the 25th July and illegally kept in custody, that even after remand by the Magistrate he was not immediately sent to jail but was taken to the house of the Superintendent of Police and kept there for more than four hours, that all these circumstances raised a strong suspicion against the voluntary character of the confession

facts.text: Supreme Court finds confession voluntary made two days after lodged in jail

anchor.surface_text: As regards the voluntary nature of the confession, the significant fact is that the confession was made on the 30th of July, that is, two days after Hem Raj had been lodged in jail, and was not in police custody or amenable to police influence.

facts.text: Gajanand eyewitness man in blue fired fatal shot corroborating confession

anchor.surface_text: W. 34, Gajanand, an eye.witness of the occurrence, deposed that the man in blue had the pistol and fired the fatal shot. This is in line with what had been stated by Nand Lal in the First Information Report

facts.text: Articles recovered from Hem Raj house on 18th July 1952 hat mask bush shirt pistol

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th of July, 1952, certain articles were recovered from Hem Rajas house-a hat, a mask., a bush shirt and a pistol. These recoveries are good independent evidence in corroboration of the confession.

facts.text: Recoveries from Hem Raj house on 25th July 1952

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th July, 1952, certain other items were admittedly recovered from Hem Rajas house and these also corroborate the confession.

facts.text: Hem Raj delivered black socks slate coloured muffler blue shorts torch to police

anchor.surface_text: Hem Raj also 1142 delivered to the police a black pair of socks, a slate coloured muffler, a blue pair of shorts and a torch. These deliveries further support the confession.

facts.text: Revolver and cartridges recovered from roof of Bansilals shop on 27th July 1952

anchor.surface_text: Then Certain recoveries were made, as stated in the confession, from the roof of Bansilals shop on 27th of July, 1952. These were a revolver and a number of cartridges.

facts.text: Sessions Judge and Judicial Commissioner acquitted Hukum Singh on appeal

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that the learned Judicial Commissioner was perfectly right in holding that this evidence by itself was insufficient to uphold his conviction and that Hukum Singh was entitled to the benefit of the doubt

issues.text: The question for consideration is whether this test [exceptional circumstances under Article 136] is satisfied in either of these two appeals

anchor.surface_text: the circumstance that because the appeal has been admitted by special leave does not entitle the appellant to open out the whole case and contest all the findings of fact and raise every point which could be raised in the High Court. Even at the final hearing only those points can be urged which are fit to be urged at the preliminary stage when the leave to appeal is asked for. The question for consideration is whether this test is satisfied in either of these two appeals.

issues.text: Whether the confession was voluntary, free and not preceded by any inducement, threat or promise by a person in authority

anchor.surface_text: That the confession was inadmissible in evidence, the prosecution having failed to establish affirmatively that it was free and voluntary and that it was not preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person in authority. It was said that as no direct or circumstantial evidence of any kind was available, the police was straining every nerve to get any one of the four persons arrested confess, so that he may be given pardon and made an approver.

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate who recorded the confession disclosed his identity and whether recording in jail vitiated the confession

anchor.surface_text: That the Magistrate who recorded the confession did not disclose his identity that he was a Magistrate to Hem Raj and that instead of recording the confession in his court room he recorded it in jail without any sufficient grounds for doing so and this circumstance also vitiated the confession. When examined under section 342, Criminal Procedure Code, he said that he made the confession under threats held out by the Superintendent

issues.text: On the question whether the confession was voluntary

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the confession was voluntary, there are concurrent findings of the courts below and there are nogrounds for going behind these findings. On the question whether material particulars of the confession have been corroborated, there are again concurrent findings.

issues.text: Whether the confession made by Hem Raj has been corroborated in material particulars

anchor.surface_text: As regards the -question whether the confession made by Hem Raj has been corroborated in material particulars, we are satisfied that there is sufficient evidence on the record to justify the Judicial Commissioners conclusion.

issues.text: Whether there was independent corroboration of material facts in the confession or only prior police knowledge

anchor.surface_text: That there was noindependent corroboration of any of the material facts contained in the confession and that whatever material has been considered as corroboration by the courts below was already in the possession of the police before the confession was recorded and therefore the confession was merely a recital of facts already in possession of the police

issues.text: Whether the evidence establishes that Hem Raj posted the threatening letter Exhibit P-5

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the evidence in conjunction with the confession satisfactorily establishes the charge under section 302/ 34, Indian Penal ,Code, against Hem Raja and also satisfactorily ves the offence under section 386, Indian Penal Code. Dr. Tek Chand very strongly criticized the conclusion reached by the Judicial Commissioner that. the letter Exhibit P 5 was posted by Hem Raj.

issues.text: Whether the confession of Hem Raj can be used as substantive evidence against Hukum Singh

anchor.surface_text: As regards the States appeal against Hukum Singh, clearly the confession of Hem Raj cannot be used as substantive evidence against him.

issues.text: Whether the evidence against Hukum Singh is sufficient for conviction or he is entitled to benefit of doubt

anchor.surface_text: Hukum Singh was entitled to the benefit of the doubt in respect of both the charges found against him. There is hardly any material on the record to justify our interference with an order of acquittal in an appeal by special leave.

arguments.claim: Confession inadmissible as prosecution failed to prove it free, voluntary, not preceded by inducement, threat or promise by person in authority

anchor.surface_text: That the confession was inadmissible in evidence, the prosecution having failed to establish affirmatively that it was free and voluntary and that it was not preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person in authority. It was said that as no direct or circumstantial evidence of any kind was available, the police was straining every nerve to get any one of the four persons arrested confess, so that he may be given pardon and made an approver.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sufficient corroboration by eyewitness, recoveries (hat, mask, pistol, cartridges, gun); prior police knowledge can corroborate retracted confession; distinguishes Mata Din as not limiting to new discoveries only

arguments.claim: Under Article 136, no exceptional circumstances warrant review; admission by special leave does not allow contesting all facts or points

anchor.surface_text: Unless it is shown that exceptional- and special circumstances exist that substantial and grave injustice has been done and the case in question presents features of sufficient gravity to warrant a review of 1135 the decision appealed against, this court does not exercise its overriding powers under article 136

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ls Nos. 58 and 87 of 1953 relate to the same occurrence, and arise out of a companymon judgment delivered by t

arguments.court_reasoning: After hearing, neither appeal raises questions within the rule

arguments.claim: Confession voluntary: made in jail two days after custody, detailed facts unknown to police, not tutored, no timely retraction

anchor.surface_text: As regards the voluntary nature of the confession, the significant fact is that the confession was made on the 30th of July, that is, two days after Hem Raj had been lodged in jail, and was not in police custody or amenable to police influence.

arguments.claim: Magistrate complied with s164 CrPC procedure: disclosed identity, warnings given, questions on voluntariness answered yes

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate who recorded the confession has been examined, and he states that he told the prisoner that he was a Magistrate and that he complied with all the requirements of law in recording the confession.

arguments.claim: Confession corroborated in material particulars by eyewitness (Gajanand), recoveries of clothes/arms/ammo/gun prior and post

anchor.surface_text: As regards the -question whether the confession made by Hem Raj has been corroborated in material particulars, we are satisfied that there is sufficient evidence on the record to justify the Judicial Commissioners conclusion.

arguments.claim: Prior police knowledge can corroborate confession; not limited to new discoveries post-confession; distinguishes Mata Din

anchor.surface_text: we see no validity in the contention that a confession can only be corroborated by evidence discovered by the police after a confession has been made and any material that is already in their possession, cannot be put in evidence in support of it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Confession can be during trial, use existing evidence; Mata Din concerns value not mode of corroboration

arguments.claim: Evidence with confession proves s302/34 IPC murder and s386 IPC against Hem Raj; he posted P-5

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the evidence in conjunction with the confession satisfactorily establishes the charge under section 302/ 34, Indian Penal ,Code, against Hem Raja and also satisfactorily ves the offence under section 386, Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Hem Raj's confession not substantive evidence against Hukum Singh

anchor.surface_text: As regards the States appeal against Hukum Singh, clearly the confession of Hem Raj cannot be used as substantive evidence against him.

arguments.claim: Evidence against Hukum Singh (writer of P-5, key P-12, door latch, seen with Hem Raj) sufficient for conviction

anchor.surface_text: The learned public prosecutor contended that Hukum Singh was the writer of the letter Exhibit P-5 and the evidence furnished by the key Exhibit P-12 found in his trouser pocket, coupled with the breaking of the door latch, and the circumstance that he was seen together with Hem Raj, was sufficient material for his conviction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: se recoveries are good independent evidence in companyroboration of the companyfession. On the 25th July, 1952, certain other items were admittedly re

arguments.court_reasoning: Insufficient to uphold conviction; entitled to benefit of doubt; no interference with acquittal in special leave appeal

arguments.claim: Concurrent findings on voluntariness and corroboration not to be interfered in Art 136 appeal

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the confession was voluntary, there are concurrent findings of the courts below and there are no grounds for going behind these findings. On the question whether material particulars of the confession have been corroborated, there are again concurrent findings.

holdings.text: Neither appeal raises questions warranting review under Article 136 as no exceptional and special circumstances showing substantial and grave injustice exist

anchor.surface_text: the circumstance that because the appeal has been admitted by special leave does not entitle the appellant to open out the whole case and contest all the findings of fact and raise every point which could be raised in the High Court. Even at the final hearing only those points can be urged which are fit to be urged at the preliminary stage when the leave to appeal is asked for. The question for consideration is whether this test is satisfied in either of these two appeals. After hearing the learned counsel. .in both the appeals we are satisfied that none of them raise any questions which fall within the rule enunciated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates principle of limited interference under Art 136; admission by special leave does not open entire case; after hearing, no fit points for full review

holdings.text: Confession by Hem Raj was voluntary with concurrent findings of lower courts and no grounds to interfere

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the confession was voluntary, there are concurrent findings of the courts below and there are nogrounds for going behind these findings. On the question whether material particulars of the confession have been corroborated, there are again concurrent findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings binding in special leave appeal; independently verified as made in jail after 36+ hours free of police influence; detailed and precise

holdings.text: Hem Raj's confession was voluntary, free, and not preceded by inducement, threat, or promise

anchor.surface_text: As regards the voluntary nature of the confession, the significant fact is that the confession was made on the 30th of July, that is, two days after Hem Raj had been lodged in jail, and was not in police custody or amenable to police influence. He had more than 36 hours to make up his mind whether to make a confession or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Made two days post-jail lodgment; detailed facts unknown/tutored by police impossible; belated retraction; police denials accepted; prior custody irrelevant

holdings.text: Magistrate complied with s.164 CrPC requirements; recording in jail an irregularity not vitiating voluntariness

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate who recorded the confession has been examined, and he states that he told the prisoner that he was a Magistrate and that he complied with all the requirements of law in recording the confession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate testified to disclosure of identity, warnings, voluntariness queries answered affirmatively; jail recording mere irregularity

holdings.text: Retracted confession corroborated in material particulars by independent evidence

anchor.surface_text: As regards the -question whether the confession made by Hem Raj has been corroborated in material particulars, we are satisfied that there is sufficient evidence on the record to justify the Judicial Commissioners conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness Gajanand, FIR consistency, recoveries of clothes/hat/mask/pistol/shorts/socks/muffler/torch/revolver/cartridges/gun case from house/roof

holdings.text: Confession can be corroborated by prior police knowledge/materials, not limited to post-confession discoveries

anchor.surface_text: we see no validity in the contention that a confession can only be corroborated by evidence discovered by the police after a confession has been made and any material that is already in their possession, cannot be put in evidence in support of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Mata Din (value not mode of corroboration); confession possible during trial using existing evidence; new facts like cartridges, pistol type, posting not known prior

holdings.text: Evidence with confession proves Hem Raj guilty under s.302/34 and s.386 IPC, including posting of threatening letter P-5

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the evidence in conjunction with the confession satisfactorily establishes the charge under section 302/ 34, Indian Penal ,Code, against Hem Raja and also satisfactorily ves the offence under section 386, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession + corroboration + presence in Beawar on posting date justify inference of posting; overall proves murder with common intention and extortion attempt

holdings.text: Confession of Hem Raj not substantive evidence against co-accused Hukum Singh

anchor.surface_text: As regards the States appeal against Hukum Singh, clearly the confession of Hem Raj cannot be used as substantive evidence against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.30 Evidence Act limits to non-substantive use only when joint trial and accused pleads guilty (not here)

holdings.text: Evidence against Hukum Singh insufficient for conviction; entitled to benefit of doubt

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that the learned Judicial Commissioner was perfectly right in holding that this evidence by itself was insufficient to uphold his conviction and that Hukum Singh was entitled to the benefit of the doubt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Key P-12, door latch break, seen with Hem Raj, handwriting on P-5 too weak absent confession; lower court acquittal justified

anchor.surface_text: Queen v. Thompson 1 , in which it had been emphasized that in order that evidence of a companyfession by a prisoner may be admissible, it must be affirmatively proved that such companyfession was free and voluntary and that it was number preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person, in authority, or that it was number made until after such inducement had clearly been removed-. The  1  1893 2 Q.B 12.

precedents.cited_proposition: in order that evidence of a confession by a prisoner may be admissible, it must be affirmatively proved that such confession was free and voluntary and that it was not preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person in authority, or that it was not made until after such inducement had clearly been removed

anchor.surface_text: Mata Din v. The Emperor 1 , wherein it was observed that a true companyfession made by a person who takes part in a murder invariably adds something to the knowledge already possessed by the investigating officer and that is the greatest test of its truth. In our opinion, the companytention raised by the learned companynsel is number well founded.

precedents.cited_proposition: a true confession made by a person who takes part in a murder invariably adds something to the knowledge already possessed by the investigating officer and that is the greatest test of its truth

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Mata Dins case 1  does number support the view companytended for. That decision merely companycerns itself with the value of a companyfession and does number relate to the nature and character of evidence that can be led to companyroborate it. It does number lay down the proposition that a companyfession cannot be companyroborated by use of materials already in possession of the police.

precedents.cited_proposition: concerns the value of a confession

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the learned companynsel. .in both the appeals we are satisfied that neither of them raise any questions which fall within the rule enunciated above.

outcome.relief_summary: Neither appeal raises substantial questions warranting interference under Article 136; lower courts' decisions upheld - conviction of Hem Raj under Sections 302/34 and 386 IPC confirmed, acquittal of Hukum Singh confirmed
